This is a building set for the 20 standard amino acids with pins/holes for assembly. It allows for assembly of a peptide chain, understanding of peptide torsion angles, amino acid stereochemistry, and sidechain identification.

Each residue requires one Calpha, one peptide-omega (the peptide bond linkage), and one side chain. The exception are Glycine, which has a special Calpha backbone, and Proline which contains a specialized backbone and sidechain model. The terminal residues can be capped with N-term and C-term.

It is highly recommend to scale these up by at least 12X (1200%) so the pins are sufficiently strong. Print with a raft, or use a brim with a very small offset (0.1-0.2mm) to help ensure that the contacting spheres will stay on the build plate. It can be useful in some cases to intentionally move the object slightly below the build plate to maximize the number of atoms that contact the build plate. Supports are needed in almost all cases.
EDIT: Link to the Blender plugin used to create these models: https://github.com/paukstelis/MolPrint

Amino acids are the building blocks of the proteins, which are in turn the primary molecules that enable life to perform intricate chemical reactions. These models provide a starting point for understanding stereochemistry, how amino acids polymerize, the nature of the peptide bond, and the different properties of amino acid side chains.

• Stereochemistry
  • Amino Acids
  • Torsion angles

title: Mini Spray Bottles Holder for Wanhao i3 Maker Select V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After seeing Nerys' Wanhao i3v2 Maker Select Spray Bottle Mount v3, I decided to craft my own version for the two small Walmart travel spray bottles I use to clean my PEI build surface. I keep windex in the blue one and isopropyl alcohol in the other. The two holes/sockets are 32.5mm diameter designed to the rough specs of the Walmart travel bottles. I included a pic of the bottles since I couldn't find an online listing for them.

I used Nerys' Wanhao i3v2 Maker Select Spray Bottle Mount v3 as a measurement template for my design by importing it into Fusion 360 and building my design to its measurements. Even though this is a fresh mesh, I am calling it a remix of the idea if not the model itself. This therefore means that my mini bottle holder is also based on the design of Azza's Z-Braces.

The original design has a missing section so that it could fit over a custom designed middle support foot. Mine has a missing corner so that I wouldn't have to remove all four screws to mount my bottle holder, lol.

The original M3x6mm screws won't work with this design; I recommend M3x8mm or M3x10mm screws. I recommend you have a supply of M3x6/8/10/12/etc screws as a matter of fact... they will definitely come in handy when modding your Wanhao/Monoprice i3!

description.text:
I needed a protective case for a Sony shotgun mic. Remixed a battery case big enough to add padding inside and duplicated threads on the body for a middle section as I have a limit on Z height to contend with. Nice thing about this design for starters is it won't roll off the table.

There are two options for the bottom, using a closed version or the open one in which case you have a plug to fit in it which you can glue padding to easily.

The one version with no external feature is for a middle extension. You can modify the length of it easily in sketchup to get the length right for your mic... or add a bunch and make a case for your fishing rod.

I added a 4mm hole in the top cap for a lanyard.

Cut a disc of 5mm neoprene for each end and a rectangle to fit wrapped in each end. Middle just floats free. Bubble wrap would work fine or some foam backed fabric.

title: Happy Pi Day Mini Pi Pie Coin

description.text: This is a small pie with the greek pi symbol on it. Its about the size of a large coin. Print one and give it to someone you love.

Summary

Using Fusion 360, I revolved a "side-view" of the pie through 360 degrees. Then, on the bottom of the "pan" I laid a canvas of a picture of the greek symbol. I traced the symbol (made a sketch, etc.). Then, extruded the symbol, "through-all" to the top (curved) surface of the pie. Then I used the modify->Split Face tool to create the symbol on the surface of the pie so that I could then use the push-pull tool to raise it a bit (so you can see it).

I don't know if this would classify as a Remix or a new design. There is already a 5G clip on Thingaverse but I felt the need to print out two clips to "feel" secured, so instead of printing two clips every time they wore out, I designed this hugger.

This pretty much defeats the purpose of the Smart Extruder's magnetic mount, but as I've ready someone say, "I've had so many jams and had to open up the extruder so many times, the tabs are gone". These were my sentiments exactly. I have two original Smart Extruders that are friction-fit (by the components) and I'm now starting to get Extruder Detached errors, so these clips are now a necessity. Or, buy a couple Smart Extruder+ for $300 each.

There's nothing really special to note here. There is an opening for the hot air from the heat sink to escape, maybe I can design one with a 40-60mm fan for better extraction, so there is no blockage. The 4 fingers clip in the the usual places. The upper right finger is shaved for better access to the tensioner, Otherwise, that;s about it.

I like to print these with carbon fiber for a stiffer part, as well as longevity. I believe the CF-PLA will withstand more heat than regular PLA. I've designed some LED light rails for my 5G, and after about 2-3 weeks, they've curled, so I'm running on CF-PLA versions and they seem ok so far.

I like the feel of 3 shells and 15-20% infill on these parts. Print with supports. I printed it upright and it took forever and the supports were a little challenging to clean up. Maybe this would be better printed on its back, with only a small amount of support material for the four hooks.

I hope this helps all you 5G owners.

More to come soon...

These are among my very first 3D designs. I'd appreciate any feedback!

Notes:

Notes on printing the UFO:
You can print the UFO as one piece (use the ufo.stl OR UFO_Body.stl + UFO_Ring.stl files) with a raft and supports or as 2 halves that can be glued together (use the UFO_halfRing.stl and UFO_halfBody.stl files).

I found that printing 2 halves and using a hot glue gun to put them together eliminated the need for supports and made for a smoother finished product. You can use glow-in-the dark glue for an added cool effect.

For a 2-color print, just center the body and ring files on the print bed and assign each to a different extruder. In the photo, I used HatchBox Glow-in-Dark filament for the Body and HatchBox Silver for the Ring.

Notes on printing the Rocket:
Print it upside down (ie with the nose down and the wings up) to avoid supports. I found I needed a raft to prevent it from tipping over while printing. Once done, it will stand up on its own.
Glue the 2 UFO halves together with a hot glue gun.

title: Spool Holder for Sylvian42's Trinus Spool Mounts

description.text:
This is a spool holder for the "Very Strong Trinus Spool Holder" designed by Sylvian42.
This one will hold multiple spool sizes, and has adjustable tension.

It needs two of each part, four skateboard bearings (like the ones everyone uses to make fidget spinners) a long 3/8 bolt, two 3/8 nuts, and a few washers.

To assemble, first press the bearings into each side of the two cones. It's a tight fit, but you should be able to do it by hand. Then insert the bolt into one of the tubes so the head sits in the hex. Add a washer, then one of the cones (thick end towards the tube), another washer, and the first nut. Tighten the nut down with your fingers. As you make it tighter, the cone will spin less and less freely. This sets a minimum tension in your spool.

To attach the spool, set it over the bolt so the hollow center rests on the pointy part of the cone. Add the other cone, with its pointy end toward the spool, then a washer, then the other tube, then the other nut. You can use the hex in the tube to screw the whole thing together. the tighter you screw it, the more tension on the spool.

The tubes sit in Sylvian42's brackets. They don't need to spin.

Sorry for the quick/cursory write-up. Feel free to get in touch if it's too confusing.

description.text:
I made a few modifications to hyperplanemike’s incredible design. I increased the clearance between a few of the parts to allow for easier assembly/movement.   • base2: increased hole size for rack_gear clearance, increased hole size for base4,

  • base3: increased hole size for rack_gear clearance, cut hole for fan_gear clearance

These are new parts:

  • base3_stopper: part to lock base 3 in either the collecting or harvesting position.

I call this "The Legendary Die of HMBAWT" (pronounced "Hmmbot" - acronym for "Hold my beer and watch this").

It's for those occasions when your players attempt to do something patently insane. You could just say they fail without a roll or you could have them roll the HMBAWT. It is all 1's except for the critical 20. It is also fairly heavily weighted against rolling that 20.

It isn't impossible to succeed, but it will make your players think hard before attempting really stupid things.

==============================================
Made this for my splicer costume for PAX East 2017!
..and emblazoned with Ryan Industries right on the handle!

UPDATE: The newest revision is posted here for your benefit. It includes all the new features from lessons I learned while sanding, painting, and assembling:

  • mating features for glue-up alignment
  • coarse-fit threads for easy adjustment
  • better knurling on the nut
  • correctly mirrored text (oops!)
    Originally modeled after an image of a RIGID-brand monkey wrench - the body of which is 14" long! And no, splicers don't actually use wrenches.. until now :-)

Printing
Layers thicker than 0.2mm are a sanding nightmare. Don't do it. On my printer, total print time can be less than 21 hours and all parts fit on the bed. Avoid printing with support - I learned this the hard way, as removal of strongly adhered support material in the wrench's neck is super awkward and cosmetically unnecessary.

Assembly
Notice the diagram (photo #2) - the components have mating features for easy alignment when gluing!

  • lightly sand every surface which will be glued (I use 100-grit sandpaper)
  • 2 holes are included in the wrench handle for 1/4" dowels (I used steel, but wood or plastic should work)

Painting
Sand everything, then spray. Prime it dark! Like black. I did the main body with red and some "rust"-colored highlights. Masking tape is your friend.

Leveling:
Maximize your print quality by leveling first! I use my 3 square print:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1776032

Go forth and make! :-D

description.text:
Customise your own card holder.

Step 1: Find a font
There are 3 fonts included but you can find your own too. Try here: https://fonts.google.com/
You want a chunky font to make it sturdy. Try typing your letter or word on that page to see how it looks. Remember, you can always scale the letters when you edit the SCAD file.

Step 2: Edit the 'custom.scad' file. Play around with all the settings or check the included examples. They will most likely all need adjustment especially if you change the font. If you use a different font to the ones included, you will need to add the font to the SCAD file. See how to do this here: https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Text
Or just look at the examples.

Step 3: Remix and publish this thing!

These are Inmoov's Chest Plates that have been re-joined to make larger pieces for larger printers,, the pictures tell the story,,, there- 1pc / 2pc / 4pc Versions and a picture of the original pieces the overall design has not been modified and is backwards compatible with all original parts-

There is a modded Neck and Neck Joiner that uses bolts to join it the body the neck is for the 3-point drive system designed by "Bob Huston" there was some mod work done on the bottom section of the Neck for a cleaner mating surface between the neck and chest plate and bolts to be inserted- The main reason for adding bolts is for PLA printing where Gluing is a problem,,
This Re-Mix was a bitch to do- but was worth effort, ,,Chest plats are 10mm Thick

There’s a "Test Joiner" piece for the testing out the “Dove Tail " joins before printing the large pieces- you can use this to test out glues or practice file work or thermal welding with a rotary tool or etc..,,,i made it a tight fit on purpose so bonding with Acetone/glues produce a nice clean joint,,,

SketchUp File is Included

.DWG Format -- https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2400142

-=Mindless=-

title: Shorter uni-joint and handle for Stead i cam.

description.text:
This is my uni-joint and handle derivative for Frits' steadicam. I wanted the uni-joint and the handle to be as short as possible. I printed the derivative uni-joint from aron (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14335) but just found it to be too long and bulky for my liking. (It is awesome for other uses though - it's in use in another project!) This is made mainly with two printed parts, a 5/16 male/female ball joint, a cheap $5 Arlec LED torch and a skate bearing. From the two printed parts - The main part is designed to fit into the bottom laser cut piece of the 'handle adjustment group of lasercut pieces' of Frits' steadicam.
  • The smaller piece is a spacer to hold the skate bearing in place inside the torch head.

Vitamins:
1x 5/16 male/female ball joint (typically used for small tie rod ends - get from CBC bearings for about $30ea - expensive but worth it!).
1x 608 skate bearing.
1x 5/16 x 20mm UNF bolt.
1x 5/16 UNF nut.
1x $5 Arlec LED torch from Bunnings. Instuctions:

  • Print your parts. While these are printing entertain your boredom with the following -

  • Dissect the head of the ARLEC LED torch.

    • throw the led's over your shoulder.
    • keep the thin bit of clear plastic in front of the LEDs. This will become an extra retainer for the skate bearing.

  • Use a dremel and a grinding tool to grind a hole in the middle of the clear plastic disc big enough for the brass end of the ball joint to easily fit through (give it at least 1mm clearance). Don't drill the hole because the disc can break quite easily.

  • Grab main printed part. Fit it to the lasercut part as in the picture and assemble the rest of the 'handle adjustment group of lasercut pieces'.
    Note - the printed part and first lasercut piece can orientate either way when assembling - there is a hole for the allthread on both sides of the printed part.

  • Spanner the male end of the ball joint into the big hole of the printed part. Put nut on other side if you want, but it's a tight fit anyhow.

  • handle gets assembled in this order -
    • Female end of ball joint.
    • outer head of torch goes over female end of ball joint.
    • Clear disk into head of torch - over the ball joint.
    • Skate bearing against female end of ball joint.
    • Bolt through the bearing into ball joint - use some loctite for the female section of ball joint.
    • Small printed part pushes onto skate bearing.
    • Push the small part up into the head of the torch.
    • Screw in body of torch - use loctite if needed.

  • Start becoming the next stanley kubrick!

  • Enjoy!

title: Balls For RC Cars easy to print version

description.text:
I made this remix of the original balls by Thather1 for an easier printing.
I simply cut downt about the 2/5 of the balls, now it has a flat side, so you can print it without support. Since one side of the balls will be facing towards the back of the truck, it doesn't visible. And i extended the attatching point with a ball shape so with a heat gun or a toutch of a flame you can fit a 6mm to 6.5mm ball end in, for an easier attatching to the car.

Also added a file with some adaptors:
40x20mm flat panel with 3mm hole in the middle.
30x20x15mm wide U shape with 3mm hole in the middle.
20x20x8mm U shape with 3mm hole in the middle. This one is designed to fit into the rear bumper of the 1/10 scale Traxxas Summit/Revo/E-Revo

You can print the adaptors with the settings you like, but i suggest 100% infill. just drill holes to the adapters to attatch them to your truck.

author: reeburgh

description.text:
This is an easy to print chess set. It's not fancy or overly unique, but I specifically designed it to be easy and quick to print. Every angle is 45ª or less, so no supports should be necessary (including on the knight!).

The models are a bit on the small size, feel free to scale them up to your need. They should be detailed enough. I printed a whole color half in under 3 hours at 0.2mm.

Printer:

CraftBot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15

Design

I'm learning SolidWorks for my new job as a CAD engineer for a plumbing replacement company, and one I got familiar with the revolve tool, my first thought was how easy it would be to design a chess set. So in >1 hour I designed the first draft of the pieces. It wasn't too hard, most of the difficulties came from making sure everything was easy to print. My knight looked pretty bad, it looked like a chicken. I redesigned the knight and tweaked the queen, and overall it looks pretty good (at least, I think so).

First design. Knight was a chicken, and the queen was too thin. The queen did print successfully, but it looked too thin and could give some people headaches. So I fixed them.

Alternative to the cylinder design, this allows easy cleanup after each shower.

Drainage holes implemented to prevent hold up.

Incorporates the 2.75" Oxo stainless drain.

title: Marvel Vision FPV Goggles Lens Cover

description.text:
This is a simple lens cover for MarvelVision FPV goggles to block out light when in storage.

I designed this because the Vifly 220 racing drone I have didn't have a spot to store the goggles, so I planned on hanging them outside the box, but didn't want sunlight to damage the lens. This cover only works on the outer part of the goggles, and is held in place by closing the lever arm on it. Eventually I'll design a cover for the inner part as well.

I Included two versions: version 2 can be printed vertically in case you happen to have a small print surface (but has 2 triangular sections that might let in a bit of direct light at the right angle), while version 3 should be printed horizontally but will completely block out light.

print_settings.Notes:: print with bottom face of grip touching buildplate, supports from buildplate only

description.text:
Version 2 of original: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170352

More images to come shortly-the Switch is occupied ;)

Tested left, and printing right side now. This is a complete redesign of the original with all measurements and modeling done by myself.

MUCH Inspiration from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2160493 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2154057 so kudos to them.

I was having difficulty modifying the original models the way i wanted so I took the calipers out and had at measuring. I also wanted a slightly different design of the grip itself (to lend itself for future ninjaflex). There are still one or two little tweaks i'd like to make to this one, but the base is here.

I would recommend printing at 25%+ infill to ensure that the connection of the grip to the spacer is strong (this is one of the little tweaks i'd like to make... adding a bit more of an angle, say 45% on one side). I've printed at 15 and it is sturdy but i like to know it's not going to break mid battle. Also, same as before, this prints upright with the grip touching the buildplate. Print with supports touching buildplate.

As requested, i've included the FreeCad project of this model

Printer:

Modded Prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

print with bottom face of grip touching buildplate, supports from buildplate only

comments.text: mine fits snug and doesn't come out, but yes if it is loose for some folks we could put in a notch so that the normal release mechanism works as intended. I'll make a note of it and hopefully have a rev out soon with it included.

comments.text: this wasn't intended to be the final "stage" of the controller. I'm working on printable "wrapper"/grips that slide over using ninjaflex. Plus personal style i guess-i tried to take out as much material as i thought was warranted to make it comfortable, but still provide nice surfaces for future ninjaflex wrappers.

comments.text: This is a great idea, but you lose the ability to charge your Joy Cons with this.  I would almost think it would be better if you created a clip for the top of bottom of the grip to maintain the charging ability.  Other than that nice design.

comments.text: there are connections that the joycons make to the switch. I'll try and post a picture, but if you look at the rail on the side of the joycon (at the bottom of end of the joy-con), try and see the back (between the joy-con and rail itself, there are metal connections that it makes with similar connector on the switch female-rail (at bottom end of switch).

comments.text: Actually, it is accurate in that the fast attack submarines do not have a flat spot on top.  the older, world war 2 fleet boats had flat spots on top.  The ballistic missiles subs had a flat spot on top that is a large fairing welded on top.  The fast attacks nowadays have cylindrical hulls.
comments.author: elektricin

comments.text: As an ex submariner I should tell you that submarines are not a pure cylinder, the top of the casing is actually flat, this makes it easier and safer to stand on, especially at sea, you may want to edit your print to show that. The flat part is about six feet wide normally
comments.author: Mumford

comments.text: Dont think there is such a thing as an 'ex Submariner' Once a brother of the 'Phinn, always a brother.

comments.text: I just modeled this quickly for a friend and omitted the flat top for ease. I might do a model with a little more detail which will include the actual flat top. Thanks for the input!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1DYRnV3Ngg6

These are Marco Diaz's dimensional scissors from the Disney Channel show Star vs the Forces of Evil.

The scissors measure 26 cm long and are attached at the pivot by a stack of 3 magnets, each 10mm round by 3mm thick. Once each blade is glued to a handle, a magnet is glued into the hole, it will be recessed. the third magnet will hold the two halves together and prevent them from sliding apart, but will still allow the two halves to pivot or be pulled apart to wield the blades individually.

These were modeled directly from the included screenshot, with minor modifications made to allow them to function properly.

playing with polygon autofilliing faces.

thought I would make basic drawing easier on myself with typical node transforms as used by programs like blender3d.
eg. s for scale, g for grab, r for rotate - yep rotate took some time to figure out.

now you can draw fairly easily in openscad a lot like you do in Blender3d, but with easier application of functions to your points.

polyhedronByxyz is still a work in progress:
its not a big deal too over-ride the defaults and place your own manual points, just remove the start/end face and append a different faceArray to the shell faceArray.

e() is a bit useless, but handy for simple quick objects.

print_settings.Notes:: There is minimal support required with two halves, but increases the final quality.

title: Tevo Black Widow Nozzle Fan Duct

description.text:
This is a maker-designed and tested nozzle fan duct specifically for the Tevo Black Widow with stock hot end, and has 360 degree cooling.

It incorporates fittings for thread inserts for a 40x40mm fan, and a 5mm hole for the mounting bolt. I suggest you research the required fan speeds for your desired print quality.

See photos for assembly, fitting, air flow illustration, and print suggestion. (print shown didn't have a fitted nozzle fan, and used stock stepper drivers)

Dimensions: 41mm wide, 102mm long, 52.5mm high.
Weight: 32 grams.

Autodesk public download link: http://a360.co/2ng0qqa

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

For best results, print the two halves, outer sides faced down. This is so the fan hole, inner duct, and bolt holes have optimised quality.

There is minimal support required with two halves, but increases the final quality.

Step 1

Remove support material. I like using a pocket knife, file or sandpaper to smooth out edges.

Step 2

Apply hobby glue to inner sides of the halves, use the locator to place the two halves together, and place the part on its side for a minimum of 1 hour, or until glue is completely dried.

Step 3

Install 5mm thread inserts into the holes.

NOTE: You may need to glue your thread inserts in if they are loose, or drill the hole slightly to fit them in, depending on the size thread insert, and the quality of your Black Widow prints.

Step 4

Install 40x40mm fan, and bolt into the thread inserts.

Don't over-tighten the bolts, it just needs to locate the fan and stop it from vibrating.

NOTE: Make sure the fan air flow direction is pointing down and into the duct. Also check the fan speed with your print settings, as it's not necessary to run at 100% full-time, depending on your printing quality research.

ALTERNATIVE: Use hot glue to fix a fan into place for a long term/temporary solution.

Step 5

Using a 5mm bolt and nylock nut, mount the duct onto the Black Widow gantry far lower left hole, and centre the nozzle hole with the nozzle. Make sure the BOTTOM OF THE DUCT is ABOVE THE NOZZLE TIP, to clear the print. It's for cooling only, not smoothing.

NOTE: I used a 20mm thick fan, which managed to clear the lower gantry V wheel. If you want more clearance with moving parts, use a 10mm thick 40x40mm fan.

ALTERNATIVE: Use hot glue to fix a fan into place for a long term/temporary solution.

Disclaimer

This is my first nozzle duct, and I'm mostly sharing it with fellow Tevo makers to help them on their journey. Keep an eye on the duct as it goes, and send me any design feedback for updates. If you print in PLA, as I have, bear in mind the nozzle is hot and close to the duct, so it may or may not cause drooping of the PLA part. If this happens, stop printing immediately to avoid collision and damage to your printer. It maybe worth printing in ABS in this case, or using a cutoff of 1mm sheet metal glued to the bottom of the duct to prevent warping.

As of uploading this item, I have printed 3.5 hours without any change in the shape of the duct.

A Dozen Iterations Later...

My design philosophy for printer parts is to keep the parts as lightweight as possible to reduce stepper motor load, while implementing full function and style.

I designed ten versions with an angled fan, but found too many complexities hollowing the duct. Finally, I took Dieter Rams design approach, simplified the fan position and overall body design, and created a circular outtake for greater cooling affect.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iUPb3gU6IrB

Bracket to replace parts FT3, FT26, and optionally the ends of FT17 and FT18 while also allowing room to add some 2028 corner brackets for additional structural rigidity.

Uses standard skateboard bearings (608ZZ).

Can either be used with the bearings and idler pulley that came with the FT5, or cut an 8mm rod to length and upgrade to a pulley with an 8mm bore.

If you use the stock idler stack, you'll need to remove one or both of the spacers. I removed both of the 3mm spacers and replaced them with 1.5mm. You technically could just remove either the top or the bottom one, but it's currently untested this way.

It is a very tight fit if you put the 2028 brackets in first. I recommend putting the Y-idler in place first, then add the 2028 brackets.

Update 11 Apr 2017: I've added 3 new variations of the Y-Idler bracket. Two without the spacing for the 2028 brackets, and one with the spacing for the 2028 brackets plus an additional M5 hole for peace of mind when fully removing Parts FT17 and FT18. You will need to print a mirror of each of these to make the set. I've also updated the hole spacing on the original design to allow for a better fit.

Folgertech FT-5

Chip-n-Moto is a remix of Chip'n'Bot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:485409)

This remix gives the Chip'n'Bot DC Motor Support via an L298P Ardumoto Shield
rather than the "Continuous" rotation SG90 "modification".
In performing this L298P update we can eliminate the proprietary board required for the Chip'n'Bot
and make the Chip-n-Moto a truly Open Source Project within reach of anyone with a 3D printer and a relatively small build area.

I have included copies of the original parts on this page as well as links to the original part file at the Chip'n'Bot page.

You will Need:
Arduino Uno - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01N298F54
HC-SR04 Sensor - http://www.dxsoul.com/product/hc-sr04-ultrasonic-sensor-distance-measuring-module-901133696
9v battery
9v battery connector cap with barrel connector - http://www.dxsoul.com/product/dd15-dc-9v-battery-button-power-plug-for-arduino-2560-2560r3-uno-uno-r3-328-5-pcs-901273059
2 rubber bands from Newspapers
2 Adafruit DC Motor in Micro Servo Body - https://www.adafruit.com/product/2941
1 SG90 Micro Servo - http://www.dx.com/p/towerpro-sg90-9g-mini-servo-with-accessories-12859
L298P Ardumoto - http://www.dx.com/p/l298p-avr-lpc-stm32-uno-mega-2a-motor-driver-shield-436284
5 zip-ties - "any" store
1 caster - https://www.lowes.com/pd/Waxman-1-25-in-Plastic-Swivel-Caster/3683910

| Build Instructions |

  1. Print off Wheels, Sensor Support, and Chassis, if you have trouble with the wheel hubs please print off 2x Wheel Hubs and install them into the center of the wheels.
    -If you have to use the hubs please install them into the wheels with adhesive to prevent slipping.
  2. Install the DC motors using zip-ties via the included slots and secure the motors.
  3. Install the SG90 in a vertical position in the center using 2 provided screws.
  4. Install the wheels onto the dc motors.
  5. Install the wheels using a single screw into the center of each wheel/wheel hub
  6. Install the HC-SR04 into the sensor support and affix with screws OR super glue in the coner holes.
  7. Install the servo arm onto the bottom of the sensor support.
  8. Affix the sensor support and servo arm onto the servo using a single screw in the middle of the servo arm to the gear.
  9. Install the caster wheel onto the chassis using two zip ties or screws.
  10. Prepare the wires from the servo and motors by wrapping them around the chassis to fit under the arduino board.
  11. Install the arduino uno board onto the chassis using the risers of your choice
  12. Prepare the L298P by attaching headers to pins 3, 10, 11, 12, & Vin.
  13. Mount the L298P onto the Arduino Uno Board with the headers you installed and risers of your choice.

  14. Attach:
    Pin 5 //SG90 PWM through L298P to Arduino pin 5
    Pin 7 //HC-SR04 Echo through L298P to Arduino pin 7
    Pin 8 //HC-SR04 Trigger through L298P to Arduino pin 8
    Arduino Pin 3 to L298P board PWMA
    Arduino Pin 11 to L298P board PWMB
    Arduino Pin 12 to L298P board DirA
    Arduino Pin 13 to L298P board DirB
    Arduino Vin to L298P board Vin
    Arduino GND to L298P board GND
    PWR+GND for the SG90 between the L298P to Arduino pins 5V and GND (Port)
    DC motor1 power and ground to DC Motor Connector on L298P ports 1&2
    DC motor2 power and ground to DC Motor Connector on L298P ports 3&4

The aduino sketch for Chip can be downloaded here - https://github.com/alchemaker/Chip-n-Moto

The print on the images is the fourth print total on the newly assembled printer. The first one after three 10mm cubes made to calibrate the machine.
Several fibres joined the crack. It had to be cut a little bit with a knife.

Blender view of the first version.

In case I'm curious in a few years how did I do it back then when I was young. The model was designed in Blender 2.78a by extruding a circle a few times. The rectangular hole in the central peg has been made as a boolean diff with resized cube.
The thicker top part of the peg in the second version was made by adding two cubes overlapping with the original shape. It is not the cleanest way, but worked well with Slic3r.

print_settings.Notes:: Material

title: Customizable Jar or Bottle Sleeve - Vase mode - OnShape
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model for a polymer sleeve that you can 3D print and then slide around your glass jars, bottles, etc. to protect them and avoid glass-to-glass collision e.g. when in a bag or shopping trolley.

You should customize this model!

To do so, create an account on OnShape if you don't have one, and copy the following document:
Parametric Jar Sleeve (vase mode)

Then edit the variables at the top of the stack to match your jar and export to STL with "fine" detail level.

The model is to be printed in vase mode (1 outline corkscrew mode) with 0 top or bottom layers and no infill. Slicers should be able to produce the desired outcome for the patterned base (hexagonal pattern). This has only been tested with Simplify3D and all units in millimetres.

Be sure to indicate your extrusion width and layer height to have a proper calculation of all dimensions. The segments of the hex pattern at the bottom should roughly be 2 perimeters wide (this is automatically calculated from the variables). It is advised to use some kind of tape (painter's tape) to facilitate removal from the build plate without breaking the base.

Explanation of the variables:

  • extrusionWidth: the extrusion width indicated in the slicer, a common value is 120% of your nozzle size;
  • layerHeight: the layer height indicated in the slicer;
  • sleeveHeight: the vertical height of the sides of the sleeve (not counting the patterned base);
  • diameterOrWidth: the diameter (cylindrical jars) or width (square jars) of the jar as measured with a calliper or similar. If the fit is too tight, add a few tenth of millimetre here (it was never needed in my case);
  • edgesFillet: the fillet to apply to the corners of the square cross-section. For cylindrical jars, indicate (#diameterOrWidth + #extrusionWidth) / 2 (there will be a very small flat area on each side but it is necessary to have correct bottom chamfers etc. in the end);
  • baseDiamOrWidth: measure and indicate the size (width or diameter) of the bottom face of the jar, usually smaller than the main jar size. This will produce the bottom chamfer with an overhang angle of 30 degrees (more than this would be hard to print in vase mode);
  • bottomFillet: indicate a value to smooth out the bottom chamfer edge;
  • baseLayers: thickness of the patterned base, expressed as a number of layers. More layers mean detaching the model from the printer's build plate without cracks will be easier.

Thanks

Thanks to Philip Thomas for his amazing FeatureScript "HexInFill" (that I had to fork for shell thickness < 1.0mm)

Printer:

eMotion Tech MicroDelta Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

The model is to be printed in vase mode (1 outline corkscrew mode) with 0 top or bottom layers and no infill.
Slicers should be able to produce the desired outcome for the patterned base (hexagonal pattern). This has only been tested with Simplify3D and all units in millimetres. Be sure to match the extrusion width and layer height you indicated in the OnShape model. The segments of the hex pattern at the bottom should roughly be 2 perimeters wide.

Material: for better protection, use a somewhat ductile material (I used PET-G)

Note

There can a little bit of warping on the sides of the square model but it should not affect the fit and will provide additional protection (it's not a bug it's a feature)

Satisfaction

Dat fit

Notes:

Scaled down to 50% size to make a small plant pot for a cactus. It came out at 9.8cm tall, 8.8cm diameter, inner diameter approx 7cm. (printed at this size it actually feels like holding a medieval wine goblet!)

Printed with a 0.3mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer height, 40mm/s using cheap grey PLA 210degC.

This is my very first print with a 0.3mm nozzle (my 0.4mm had died and 0.3m was the only one I had available). I'd probably increase the shell count next time I print this as it feels a little delicate (might be the 0.3mm nozzle though) and maybe nudge the infill up to 5%. For displaying on a window sill with a small house plant inside it will be more than adequate as-is.

Took around 9 hours to print.

Taking photos of an object on holiday then watching it materialise before you when you get home is awesome! I'm particularly fond of the chip that the original Urn had in the top rim being replicated in the model - adds to the authenticity.
Chip from the original urn replicated too - cool!

author: Gluon45

description.text:
Mason Jar Bioreactor

Make a low-cost bioreactor with common materials!

  • For the use with wide mouth Mason jars.

This is still a work in progress
Bioreactors are typically used when doing tissue engineering to grow the cells needed for seeding after decellularization of some type of organic matter, typically fruit, organs, or muscles. I designed this bioreactor to be very low cost and to be printed on a resin printer as to an ideal environment inside the reactor. It can be printed on a common FDM machine as well but I would keep it in a flow hood. There is a place for a bearing in the middle of the lid which takes a 16mm bearing. This is for a stirrer if you wanted to use one but it's not really needed. You can print a cap for the middle if you will not be using it.

The procedure can be found here: http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0097835#s2

I used a strawberry in my decellularization but it can be used with a lot of other things.

Some other great reads:

http://www.pellinglab.net/using-fruits-for-in-vitro-3d-cell-culture/

http://ossificatorium.blogspot.com/2013/10/biomaterial-processes-diy-tissue.html

title: Customizable Toothbrush Head Box w/ Lid

description.text: Without being too descriptive, those smells you may sometimes smell in your bathroom are from things in the air.  Those things can get on your toothbrush if you store it in your bathroom.  Blegh!  Print this up to keep your toothbrush nice and clean. :D

• Measure and adjust parameters
  • Export stl and create gcode
  • Print and enjoy
    • Extra Credit: Heat up and pinch the sides of the lid in slightly to ensure a snug fit. Pro Tip: Replace your toothbrush regularly and give this box a good washing.

comments.text: I have an LED booklight that keeps getting the on switch bumped in my backpack. I tried to put an off the shelf tooth brush holder on it to keep it from running down the battery, but it was a little too small. I tried your design as is, was also just a little small. I scaled it 1.2X and it was perfect! Thank you!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: That's probably an even better use for the design than holding a toothbrush. Very cool idea. You're truly a maker. What did you print on? It looks good.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Putting your toothbrush in a box when wet is a bad idea. You will not get air born germs on it but, instead you will get bacteria that thrives in dark damp places to grow because the toothbrush will take longer to dry.
comments.author: mikeq

comments.text: Good point.  I'll make sure I always dry mine.  The main reason I made and use this box is due to lack of vertical space to store my toothbrush in.  This makes it fit neatly in my mirror cabinet.  I also have the good "fortune" of living in a rather arid climate so humidity and moisture are less of an issue.

circle to ellipse

Delta=0.01;

module connector (height,radius,eccentricity)
translate([0,0,0])
{
hull() {
linear_extrude(height=Delta)
circle(r=radius);
translate([0,30,height - Delta])
linear_extrude(height=Delta)
scale([1,eccentricity])
circle(r=radius);
}
}

module tube(height, radius, eccentricity=1, thickness) {
difference() {
minkowski() {
connector(height,radius,eccentricity);
cylinder(height=height,r=thickness);
}
translate([0,0,-(Delta+thickness)])
connector(height + 2* (Delta +thickness) ,radius, eccentricity);
}
}

tube(60,48.5,0.5,1);

tube2(60, 50, 1, center = false);

module tube2(height, radius, wall, center = false)
translate([0,0,-59])
{
difference() {
cylinder(h=height, r=radius, center=center);
cylinder(h=height, r=radius-wall, center=center);
}
}

author: zabbazabba

description.text:
Does your layer fan make a sphere of air focused on the sweet spot?
checkout the video test below (using radial fan 4020) for aerodynamic and then test yours to see if you are using all air output, or just part of it.

There is an interesting video for high speed printing test to compare four fanduct models including this one done by ruiraptor:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0llj3pBltA

Source code included (blender files, .obj).

Support:

Hotends:

  • E3D
  • E3D Titan
  • Tevo Stock (chimera single nozzle)

Radial Fans:

  • 4020
  • 5015

Sensors:

  • No sensor
  • LJC18A3 (Set X: +49mm, Y: -19mm)
  • LJ12A3 (Set X: +49mm, Y: -19mm), it'll fit in LJC18A3 18mm hole, the nuts is bigger
  • BLTouch (Set X: +39mm, Y: -21mm)
  • SN04 (Set X: 39mm, Y: -8mm)

Features:

  • Fang design, you can see whats going on while printing, you can reach and remove oozing before they ruin the print.
  • Very efficient air blow, minimal curves , no hard angles... to avoid air colliding (air current eliminating)
  • SPHERE air concentrating!!! all air blowing focused on nozzle tip, then get reflected to all directions (see the video).
  • Adjustable height, so it fit best for your own configuration.
  • Balanced air distribution, blow from 2 sides against each other, the air escape from other 2 side, no pushing from one side only, Also Radial fan gives more air at one side of it's output hole, perpendicularly plugging design will split the air current equally for each tube.
  • Compatible with E3D, Tevo Stock hotend and many others (please comment if yours fit too)
  • Support both 4020 and 5015 Radial fan models
  • LED holder, very recommended, huge lighting focus, even for dark

Help:

Which file you should print
There are two main models, Radial Fan 4020 (40 X 20 mm) and Radial Fan 5015 (50 X 15 mm).
each model has 4 versions to support all sensors.
which identified by file name as: Radial Fan Fang [Size] [Sensor].stl
Example: if you have radial fan 5015 and LJC18A3 sensor, then you should print:
Radial_Fan_Fang_5015_LJC18A3.stl

Printing Tips

  • you can add brim support if the first layer did not stick will.
  • you need to add printing support for sensors edition, select the proper support type so you don't add support inside, 40% infill is recommended, because of sensor mount.
  • if you don't have layer fan before and you couldn't print without one, you can make a quick temporary setup for your radial fan (cardboard & duck tape), to get the first print with poor quality, then install it and print a better one.

Installing

  • you should adjust the height to make the hangs tips higher than the nozzle tip by 2 to 3mm.
  • if you are using sensor edition, update your firmware to set sensor offset.
  • for tevo stock hotend: if you get rapid click sound, you need to add washers between hotend fan and the model, because you got pop up tips while printing (I'm working on solution for that)

Adding LED light

  • buy LED strip
  • cut the first 3 led's (cut on line)
  • connect wires to hotend fan, red to red and black to black (it'll be always on)
  • stick it under hotend fan using silicon bar or super glow, on the fan duct tip, it'll be tilted to direct light to nozzle tip

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Ne7hcn2nK5w" ></iframe>

How to adjust it to make your own edition

Follow this steps as shown in the animation above:

  • download and open blend file using blender (get it free from www.blender.org)
  • press 3 on num pad, to go to front view
  • right click on the fang, to select
  • press tab key, to enter edit mode
  • press z key, to show all points
  • press and hold ctrl + left mouse key, to select points
  • press z key, to go back to solid view
  • drag axis, to make the wanted adjustment
  • press tab key, to exit edit mode
  • select all parts by right click & hold shift
  • File > Export > .stl, then check "selection Only" then Export STL

comments.text:
Ok that bull fan fang whatever with the 40mm fan was the best potential but the reason its performance was low was because the tips were screwed up and not even remotely pointing in the right place. The tips need to be blowing horizontal so they just nip the tip of the nozzle. On that one they were just cooling the bed off and any part of the printed model that happened to pass underneath.
I am currently using a dual fang cooler on my CR10 with a 22cfm 40mm fan. I want to use that fan instead of the radial fan because that radial fan probably only puts out 5cfm and the resistance of the fangs is high. You pretty much need to run it at 100% to get mediocre cooling at best. With my 22 cfm fan I only run it at 40% for most things. I'd like to use it with my e3d conversion and was hoping to find a fan here that would work.
I'd love to see this fan with the nozzles slightly offset for a 40mm fan. By offset I mean the left duct pointed back 2 or 3 mm with the right duct pointed the other way by the same amount so the effect at the nozzle would be a small whirlwind/tornado.
comments.author: Consaka

comments.text:
for your first point (air hit the bed not the nozzle) do you mean that height adjustment (6mm) was not enough for you ?
for the second point of "tornado", when printing very pointy tips (like deer horns) unbalanced air blowing like one side with no equal blowing from the other side will cause unbalanced printed part, this will lead to poor print quality
comments.author: Consaka

comments.text:
No it has more to do with where the tip is pointed. Keep in mind air leaving the tip will disperse a bit as it pulls in other air. The tips of the horns should not be pointing down any more then can be helped. While you don't want air blowing on the extruder tip you do want it as close as possible to the extruder tip. If a bit of air hits the tip that should be ok as long as it is not the main stream. My comment on the horn arrangement had to do with one that was tested. I haven't had time to look at yours specifically.
For the tornado effect I think you need to revisit my comment. The tornado effect effectively causes air to move in a circular pattern around the part thus cooling more then it would otherwise. Besides that fact I stated that the edge of the stream would still hit directly below the extruder on both sides. With my fan I would never need all the air it puts out (22cfm), so some being offset should work pretty good. The poorly performing radial fans might be different. I have 3 or 4 of them and they perform poorly at best with horns.
comments.author: Lion4H

comments.text:
not sure about your experiments, but Radial fans proved to be more than enough, you may need to set it on 80% max too.
if the duct tips were horizontal, it will blow all at nozzle, for example when you home Z, you cannot lower the duct below the nozzle, it'll hit the bed, so horizontal tips will only blow at nozzle, that why they has to be tilted down.
About tornado effect, this is a very theory talk, if I will consider it, I have to simulate it first,
two powerful parallel air current (opposite in direction) most likely will cause many small tornado all the way in between ,like what you see in Jupeter planet photo,
another thing about tornado, they has calm area in the middle (the eye),
still, turning around air blow will twist the thin parts , even for thin walls, so there must be balanced force from both side to support the object structure
comments.author: Consaka

comments.text:

My previous fang tip designed for the CR10 hot end was made out of ABS and a print gone bad snagged both horns and ripped them off. Loving that adjustability and your horns are flattened to the horizontal plane just like they should be. Now to see if this e3d setup will print without leaving zits all over.
Two air streams pointed right at each other are going to have a low flow area where they meet and change direction. A 2 or 3 mm offset should just help create more of a sheer force id think. Just thoughts with no way to really test. Pretty low on my priority list as well since these seem to work pretty well.
The only thing better would be one made for the big tall 40 mm fan I am using. comments.text:
i totally understand what you are saying.
i'll try to explain a little. e3d's original fan holder has a problem when printing high temp materials (nylons, polycarbonate, etc...) at high speeds (100mm/s and above). you will get heat creep, so if that material needs more retracting for a cleaner print - you will definitely end up with a clog.
here is a picture to make it more clear - https://imagebin.ca/v/3RGz8T0vSSJU
as you can see, the red line marks where the bottom part of the airflow is (approximation, and ofcourse air will move like a cone - but this is just to illustrate). the space between that line and the heatblock itself ( + exposed nozzle) gets very little to no cooling.
you can fix that by lowering the cooler on the hotend, but then it doesn't hold so well (and also you will have a problem with the radial fang) or you could use the holder i am working on - it sits a little below where the e3d one sits (~3-4mm instead of 5-6mm if you use the original) and it also has the wind tunnel pointing at a more slanted angle (~15 degrees) towards the bottom - which is the part you want to cool anyways (it does not help to cool the top of the heatsink).
comments.author: Lion4H

comments.text:

but for the length, I think it is standard to have 36 led in 50cm led aluminum strip,

for me, I bought a good one, which I regret, I got overlighted object like you see in the photo,

so I advice you to buy a cheap led strip, which has low wattage, 50cm cost you about $2

two fans might be needed when you have less efficient fanduct design, like some designs with 90 degree angle (air collision and elimination) and unfocused air blowing end (not all output air hit the sweet point)

description.text:
A 9 level pascal triangle realized in three dimensions.
The height at each level is computed by adding the level number to all the values at each level.

This represents this eq: a = n! / r! * (n - r)! - which is the basis for the Pascal's Triangle. What i have done to compute the height is just take the level number n starting from 1 (not 0) and add it to each value of a computed in above eq.

http://mathworld.wolfram.com/PascalsTriangle.html

Could not go beyond 9 levels due to my printers; build volume limitation...

comments.text: Does this represent a mathematical equation? It looks pretty cool.
comments.author: The_Batter

comments.text: Yes, it represents this eq: a = n! / r! * (n - r)! - which is the basis for the Pascal's Triangle. What i have done to compute the height is just take the level number n starting from 1 (not 0) and add it to each value of a computed in above eq.

It's glitch, bob's keytool from reboot, my first attempt at designing something like this, so it's probably far from specs, but if you just want your own glitch, then just print it and put it together.  
You'll have to glue the gear onto the top piece, the twist lock part is too shallow to be of use, and I cant fix it without starting from scratch. When I was designing it, I saved it and exported the stl file. Soon after, the computer spazzed out and corrupted the design file.  
There's a hole almost all the way through the end pieces so it works as a hinge, just put a piece of filament into it, then you can store stuff in it.  
Edit: I uploaded pics of the keytool after it was printed, but printer was acting up and the plastic didnt want to stick, so it's kinda wavy looking a little. I uploaded an STL of the completed, but solid version of glitch also so you can see how it looks all assembled when the printer is working right.

comments.author: Offline

comments.text: It's not completely necessary. Sometimes if you are printing something with a small cross section, it starts puting new layers on top of old layers before the old layers have time to cool and that can cause problems. A fan can help layers cool faster without having to slow your print speed way down.

Lungs Model built using a plastic bottle, three baloons (two of them red) and two flexible pipes.
The baloon at the bottom works like the diaphragm, the muscle that expands and contracts causing lungs to fill with air and then empty out again. The movement of the red balloons matches the breathing, when a person breathe in, the lungs fill with air, that’s because the diaphragm expanded making room for air to get in through the bronchus (in our model the joint pipes). When a person breathe out, the diaphragm contracts pushing all the air out of your lungs.
The students can enjoy creating a new face for the model.
We have choosed a popular character Dottor Culocane from a famous caroonist and youtuber:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mFQukpkgoSI

Overview The baloon at the bottom works like the diaphragm, the muscle that expands and contracts causing lungs to fill with air and then empty out again. The movement of the red balloons matches the breathing, when a person breathe in, the lungs fill with air, that’s because the diaphragm expanded making room for air to get in through the bronchus (in our model the joint pipes). When a person breathe out, the diaphragm contracts pushing all the air out of your lungs.
The students can enjoy creating a new face for the model.

Built the model Cut the bottle in the middle.
Create two small holes on the bottle cap.
Insert the two red baloons on the cap holes.
Insert two small pieces of flexible pipe on the hole, this allows the air flow inside the ballons.
Join the two pipe end with the piece built with 3d printer.
Cut the top of the third baloon and apply it on the bottle bottom. Fix it with the ring built with 3d printer.
Create with the students a funny face for the model, print it and apply it on the top of the bottle.

Materials: plastic bottle, three baloons (two of them red) and two flexible pipes.
3d print of the .stl file attached.

description.text:
Update added a new version with a 10° angle to glide better over grass.

My version of a glide bar for Liam (https://www.facebook.com/groups/319588508137220/).

Original version was bolted to the sides of the box, and slightly too big for my printer (20cm circular bed). So I designed a version that bolts to the bottom instead, and is just as wide as the box that is Liams Body.

If you decide to remix it in OpenSCAD I recommend disabling the Minkowski function used to create round edges, it takes a couple of minutes to render with it activated ;)

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I suggest using brim and rotate the bar so its laying flat on the print bed. I haven't printed it myself just yet, waiting for spare parts to my printer.

It's basically a frame brace for your X axis. It works really good with this frame braces: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162.
It's hollow and you can put all of your cables through, but you will need to use another wire to pull the last few connectors through.
If you like it, I can make it even better - It's kind of hard to get it in the frame itself.
So first you put both struts together with the washer 2 and put the washers 1.2 on, and screw them to the inner end of the thread. Later put in all the cables except the ones from the hot bed. Put the strut in the frame, tighten the inner washers and put on the outer ones and tighten them. Then pull the last remaining wires through and you're good to go.

Oh, and If you like it, please tell, since I'm planing to remix these supports, so you can tighten them on the other too:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2074478
Maybe I will even make the same thing for the bottom of the printer.
Enjoy :)

Oh yeah, and one more thing, after you tighten the middle connecting washer, don't try to get it back apart, or you will crack the struts

title: HyperLite Locking Camera w/ Transponder Hole

description.text:
Remixed this so there is a transponder hole in the side while being protected. Added more supports in the middle and some holes for zip ties so you can strap something underneath and on top and use a single zip tie for both.

New Files up. Changed cutout for the transponder to a rectangle and made it so you could put it on both sides. Added a version w/o the back plate too. Both versions have an area for mounting a LED on the back.

Mount is for a 2.1 Lens at 40 degrees.

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

40

Notes:

Print slow for best quality. Heated bed at 60c

comments.text: You may want to put transponder hole on other side as well, as I've been to races where they will change depending on sun location in relation to timing gate.
